Surface visualizationÂ¶

This section describes where are the main surfaces generated by the pipeline, and how you can visualized them using python or R. This example will use the subject HC001, session 01 from the MICs dataset, and all paths will be relative to the subject directory or out/micapipe/sub-HC001_ses01/

On the following examples weâ€™ll load and visualize a single subject surfaces. The subject surfaces are distributed through different directories, they look like:

sub-HC001/
â””â”€â”€ ses-01
    â”œâ”€â”€ anat
    â”‚Â Â  â””â”€â”€ surfaces
    â”‚Â Â   Â Â  â”œâ”€â”€ conte69          # conte69 surfaces
    â”‚Â Â   Â Â  â”œâ”€â”€ micro_profiles   # MPC connectomes and surfaces
    â”‚Â Â   Â Â  â””â”€â”€ morphology       # Thickness and curvature surfaces
    â””â”€â”€ func
     Â Â  â””â”€â”€ surfaces             # rsfMRI surfaces and connectomes

Each native surface parcellation is found inside the subjectâ€™s freesurfer directory and contains the string mics.annot:

freesurfer/
â””â”€â”€ sub-S03_ses-SES01
    â””â”€â”€ label
        â”œâ”€â”€ lh.schaefer-400_mics.annot
        â””â”€â”€ rh.schaefer-400_mics.annot

This example uses the packages nilearn, numpy and matplotlib for python. R uses the libraries RColorBrewer and viridis. The first step in both languages is to set the environment:

Python

R

# Set the environment
import numpy as np
from nilearn import plotting
import matplotlib as plt

# This variable will be different for each subject
subjectID = 'sub-HC001_ses-01'

# Here we define the atlas
atlas = 'schaefer-400'

# Set the environment
library("RColorBrewer")
library("viridis")

# Set the working directory to your subjec's directory
setwd("out/micapipe/sub-HC001/ses-01")

# This variable will be different for each subject
subjectID <- 'sub-HC001_ses-01'

# Here we define the atlas
atlas <- 'schaefer-400'
